State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences No. 27 Taoyuan South Road Taiyuan 030001 China Understanding the role of hydroxyl groups on SiO2 in regulating the electronic and structural properties of copper and cobalt species is of great significance for direct conversion of syngas to ethanol. Here we report that the hydroxyl groups are efficiently modulated by pretreatment of SiO2 with H2O2 at different temperatures and obtain the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with appropriate amounts of Si-OH. It can simultaneously possesses the highest CO conversion (37.8 %) and ethanol selectivity (29.0 wt %), together with excellent ethanol space-time yield of 17.0 mg/mLcat·h. The excellent performance can be attributed to the fact that the Si-OH promotes the dispersion and reduction degree of Cu and Co by a strong metal-support interaction, resulting in the formation of more Cu+-Co0 synergistic active sites, known as the key sites for C2-oxygenate formation. Among them, Co0 species facilitate the dissociation of CO and generat a large amount of CHx ⁎ intermediates, which could react with the CO⁎ species adsorbed on the adjacent Cu+ species, greatly stimulating the formation of ethanol. More significantly, Operando DRIFT characterization revealed that the moderate incorporation of hydroxyl groups effectively suppresses CHₓ⁎ hydrogenation into methane. Consequently, a substantial amount of CHx ⁎ intermediates engaged in the propagation of the carbon chain, thus facilitating the production of ethanol. This investigation offers a facile preparation method and insights to improve the ethanol yield for direct syngas conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO hydrogenation Ethanol synthesis CuCo-based catalyst Hydroxyl groups Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the transformation of the global energy structure and the increasing awareness of environmental protection, the construction of a clean, efficient, safe, and sustainable modern coal clean utilization system has attracted special interest in the C1 chemistry field [1–4]. The one-step conversion of coal-based syngas (H2 and CO) into value-added liquid fuels and chemicals, especially ethanol, can not only achieves clean and efficient utilization of non-petroleum carbon resources, but also has important significance for ensuring energy and food security [5–7]. Enormous research efforts are being continued in using heterogeneous catalysts with the aim of enhancing ethanol selectivity, yet significant challenges persist in large-scale industrial production [8–11]. Especially due to the broad distribution of products and the difficulty in pinpointing the actual active sites, the discussion of reaction pathway for ethanol synthesis directly from syngas, is still ongoing. Precisely controlling the coupling reaction between dissociated CO (CnHx*) and non-dissociated CO(CO*/HCO*) activated species is crucial for achieving higher ethanol catalytic activity [12]. CuCo-based catalysts has proven to be a valuable alternative in the synthesis of ethanol from syngas, owing to the great activity and efficient production of C2+OH at mild reaction conditions [7,13–15]. Huang et al [16] designed a CuCoAl|ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst with an appropriate [H*]/[C*] ratio displayed a higher STYROH and ROH selectivity in CO hydrogenation. The relative proportion and proximity of Cu and Co species also profoundly affect the catalytic performance [17,18]. Moreover, the dispersion and the electronic structure of Cu and Co on the surface of SiO2 support could be altered by introducing La2O3 or CTAB, which directly influences the insertion process of CHxO* species into CxHy* species in CO hydrogenation [19–21]. Nevertheless, the complex nature of these modified catalysts makes it difficult to elucidate their structure-activity relationship. On the other hand, the uncontrolled particle size and variable valence caused by the poor solubility (maximum Cu solubility in Co is 9 %) of Co and Cu species make the active sites on CuCo based catalysts still remain unclear at the molecular level [22]. For the above reasons, there is still much controversy about the adsorption and activation centers of CO and H2, as well as the mechanism of carbon chain growth during ethanol formation. Notably, mesoporous SiO2 is a potential support in C1 chemistry due to its unique properties such as high thermal stability, abundant silicon hydroxyl groups (Si-OH), large specific surface area, and pore structure. Among them, the large pores can quickly achieve mass and heat transfer. Essentially, the prominent decorative properties of inert SiO2 stem from its abundant Si-OH on the surface. The formation of metal oxides with unique structures on the catalyst surface could be manipulated and controlled through Si-OH induced the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) effect [23–25]. For instance, Lu et al [26] found that Cu-Fe/SiO2 catalyst through the pretreatment of SiO2 with ammonia displayed superior yield of higher alcohols, owing to the generation of lots of Cu active sites and high dispersion of Fe species, enhancing the synergistic effect of Cu-Fe dual active sites. Similarly, SiO2 pretreated with nC1-C5 alcohol enhances its hydrophobicity, which is beneficial for promoting the dispersion of Rh and improving the Rh+/Rh0 ratio, thereby enhancing the CO insertion [27]. Yu et al [28] adjusted the density of surface hydroxyls by varying the calcination temperature of SiO2, and discovered that a reasonable amount of surface Si-OH facilitated the establishment of moderate Rh-Mn interactions. Wang et al [29] proposed that there is a linear relationship between the Si-OH on the surface of SiO2 and the amount of Cu+ species in Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, DFT calculations revealed that during the conversion of syngas to ethanol, the interaction between CH3 and CO shifts from attraction to repulsion with an increase in hydroxyl coverage [30]. Despite heavy research efforts, there has been no direct evidence to reveal the specific role of structural Si-OH in the CuCo/SiO2 catalysts for ethanol synthesis from syngas. As indicated above, the Si-OH played a crucial role on the dispersion, localization, and anchoring of Cu and Co species, CuCo/SiO2 catalyst was chosen as the model catalyst and applied for direct syngas conversion. As will be reported here, the content of Si-OH on the surface of SiO2 were precisely controlled by changing the pretreatment temperature of H2O2, and it was utilized as the modified support for catalyst preparation. As a result, the optimal CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with a suitable content of Si-OH exhibited the best catalytic performance with a high selectivity to ethanol (29.0 %), the conversion of CO (37.8 %), and a space time yield (STY) toward HA (58.6 mg/mLcat·h). Combined with rigorous characterization and investigation, the microstructure of catalysts and their impact on product distribution were explored in detail. It is demonstrated that the abundant Cu+-Co0 synergistic active sites regulated by Si-OH promote the efficient synthesis of ethanol. This work offered potentials in rational design of high-efficiency, selective, and stable ethanol synthesis catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Before being used for catalyst preparation, the purchased SiO2 support needs to be washed with H2O and calcined at 600 °C to remove the adsorbent on the surface. The synthesis method of catalyst is as follows. Si-TH: In a typical synthesis, 5.0 g SiO2 was added to a three-necked flask of polytetrafluoroethylene with 80.0 mL (30 wt %) H2O2, and the suspension was transferred to an oil bath with continuous stirring and refluxed at T°C for 7 h. The obtained precipitate was filtered and washed with distilled water. The samples were subsequently dried at 120 °C for 10 h in a static oven and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. The samples obtained were labeled Si-TH, where H stands for H2O2 and T for the temperature of H2O2 pretreatment (T = 70 °C, 100 °C, 120 °C). The sample was labelled (Si) for the unmodified SiO2. CuCo/(Si-TH): A series of CuCo-based catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWM) method. To be brief, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.87 g, 2.99 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.67 g, 2.77 mmol) were dissolved in 3.0 mL anhydrous ethanol. Whereafter, the modified Si-TH support (2.00 g) was soaked into the obtained mixed nitrate solution. The resulted samples was ultrasonicated at 25 °C for 1 h, dried at 120 °C for 10 h, and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The final catalysts obtained were labeled CuCo/(Si-TH) with a molar ratio Cu/Co = 1:1. The reference catalyst without H2O2 pretreatment was labeled CuCo/(Si). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption was performed on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3000. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated by employing the BET method. The pore size (Dp) and pore volume (Vp) were measured by employing BJH method. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku MiniFlex II X-ray diffractometer, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV, 40 mA, a scanning rate of 4° min-1, a step size of 0.02° s-1, and a 2θ ranging from 5∼90°. The TEM characterization were implemented on a JEM-2100F equipped with HRTEM and EDX. Firstly, the reduced catalyst was finely ground into a powder and dissolved in ethanol, and then, sonicated for a moment. Afterward, a small amount of supernatant was dropped on the surface of the ultrathin carbon molybdenum film network. Then put it into the sample cassette for detection after drying at room temperature. in situ CO Diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ CO DRIFTS) were carried out using a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer at a spectrum resolution of 4 cm-1, a scanning range of 4000–400 cm−1 and an accumulation of 64 scans. Prior to each measurement, the calcined catalyst was reduced online under the flow of 10 % H2/N2 (15 mL/min) at 400 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the sample was exposed to a Ar flow (25 mL/min) for 30 min and cooled down to 270 °C. After the baseline is stable, a flow of CO was switched in and kept for half an hour and corresponding spectrum was recorded every minute. Finally, the Ar flow was re-injected and purged for 30 min to remove the residual CO, meanwhile the spectra recorded until the signal no longer changed. The surface Si-OH contents of both the untreated and pretreated SiO2 supports were also analyzed by infrared spectroscopy. First, the sample was placed in the reaction cell. Then, it was purged with N2 for 2 h at a temperature of 120 °C to remove moisture. When the temperature dropped to 25 °C, the infrared spectrum of the sample was recorded with air as the background. Operando Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform (DRIFT) analysis was executed using a NICOLET iS50 FT-IR apparatus. Prior to the measurements, the catalyst sample was pressed and placed in an in-situ reaction chamber. Afterwards, the catalyst was heated up to 400 °C in H2 stream. After three hours of reduction process under atmospheric pressure, the temperature gradually cooled down to 270 °C. Concurrently, a flow of He was introduced to the cell and the pressure was adjusted to 2.5 MPa. Background elimination was implemented when the exhaust gas flow reached equilibrium. Finally, He was switched to syngas for 1 h of insitu reaction, and the corresponding infrared spectral data was continuously recorded. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was characterized using a TP 5080 employed with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). About 0.10 g catalysts were loaded in a quartz tube and pretreated in a stream of N2 at 200 °C for 60 min to remove water and impurity gases adsorbed on the surface. When the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C, the catalyst was uncovered to 10 % H2/N2 and raise the temperature to 800 °C. The depletion signals of H2 was monitored by TCD. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy data of Cu were used to analyze the compositions and electronic states of the reducted catalysts, which were recorded using an AXIS ULTRA DLD apparatus. 2.3 Catalytic activity studies CO hydrogenation were carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed stainless steel tubular micro-reactor (6 mm in diameter, 300 mm in length). Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was heated to 400 °C using a temperature controller and activated in situ for 6 h at atmospheric pressure in a flowing 20 % H2/N2. After that, the reaction temperature was cooled down to 270 °C in a reducing atmosphere. Subsequently, the gas flow was switched to syngas (H2/CO ratio of 2.0) and the reaction pressure was pressurized to 5.0 MPa. After the reaction has been running stably for 10 h, the product was collected and analyzed. In gaseous tail gas, the H2, CO, CH4, CO2 and hydrocarbons, DME, CH3OH were measured using a GC4000A connected to TCD and FID, respectively. In the liquid phase, the H2O and methanol were analyzed using a GC4000A equipped with a TCD. All alcohol products were determined with a GC-7AG connected with a FID. The carbon balance analyzed and calculated for each catalyst was also kept within the range of 98 %-102 % to ensure the reliability of the evaluation results. CO conversion (X CO), product selectivity on carbon basis (S i) and the mass selectivity of alcohol i in alcohol products (W i) can be calculated based on the following formula. (1) X CO = n CO , in − n CO , out n CO , in × 100 % (2) S i = v i × n i , out − n i , in n CO , in − n CO , out × 100 % (3) W i = R i , s f i , m ∑ i R i , s f i , m × 100 % The n CO,in and n CO,out represent the moles of CO at the inlet and outlet, respectively. S i and vi stands for the selectivity of C mol and carbon number of the products, such as hydrocarbons, DME and CO2. R i,s and f i,m represents the area ratio of alcohol i on the chromatogram and quality correction factor, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Syngas conversion over the CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts is investigated at 270 °C, 5.0 MPa, 3000 h-1, and H2/CO = 2/1. The catalytic performances are shown in Table 1 and Fig. 1 . Compared with untreated CuCo/(Si) catalyst, the CO hydrogenation activity of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts treated with H2O2 showed significant differences. In comparison, the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst showed the best ethanol selectivity of 29.0 wt % and CO conversion of 37.8 %. Interestingly, with the increase of SiO2 pretreatment temperature, the total alcohol yield kept increasing from 23.8 to 58.6 mg/mLcat·h, and the yield of ethanol increases from 4.2 to 17.0 mg/mLcat·h. Further increasing the pretreatment temperature of SiO2 significantly reduces the synthesis of ethanol. Especially from Fig. 1, it can be intuitively observed that the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst exhibits the highest CO conversion, ethanol selectivity and yields of total alcohol and ethanol, which are far superior to other CuCo catalysts. In addition, the high selectivity of CH4 may be attributed to the strong C-O dissociation ability of Co0 in CuCo-based catalysts, and the hydrogenation energy barrier of CHx ⁎ is much lower than that of CO insertion. The catalytic performance of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts indicates that the appropriate H2O2 pretreatment temperature for SiO2 plays a pivotal role in the syngas to ethanol process. 3.2 The structural features of CuCo/(Si-Th) catalysts To verify the initial hypothesis that H2O2 pretreatment of SiO2 support has the effect of increasing the amount of Si-OH, the Si-TH support were characterized by in situ CO-DRIFTS. Fig. 2 (a) shows the skeletal infrared spectra of the control (Si) support and Si-TH support pretreated with H2O2 at different temperatures. According to literature research, the 3839–3477 cm-1 range belongs to the characteristic peak of Si-OH [31,32]. It can be clearly seen that compared with the untreated (Si) support, the Si-OH characteristic peaks of the SiO2 support after H2O2 pretreatment have significantly increased. And with the increase of H2O2 pretreatment temperature, the quantity of Si-OH follows the order (Si-120H)>(Si-100H)>(Si-70H)>(Si). This is consistent with our expected results, indicating that H2O2 heat treatment of the SiO2 is indeed beneficial for increasing the Si-OH groups on the surface of SiO2. Fig. 2 (b) and (c) show the in situ CO-DRIFTS curves of the reducted CuCo/(Si-100H) catalysts when they are saturated with adsorbed CO and completely purged with Ar, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the CO adsorption peak at 1997 cm-1 is attributed to the bridge adsorption of Co0 2(CO) on metallic Co0, which promotes the dissociation adsorption of CO and produces dissociative adsorption species C⁎ and O⁎. It is evident that the adsorption intensity of Co0 on CO follows the order CuCo/(Si) > CuCo/(Si-100H) > CuCo/(Si-120H) > CuCo/(Si-70H). The adsorption peaks observed at 2171 and 2121 cm-1 correspond to the gaseous CO [33,34], with the latter peak (2121 cm-1) partially originating from CO adsorbed on Cu+ sites. After the reduced CuCo/(Si-100H) catalysts surface was purged with Ar and reached steady state, as exhibited in Fig. 2(c), a typical Cu+-CO adsorption peak was distinctly observed at 2123 cm-1, which was stable no matter in purging or heat treatment. Interestingly, the CO adsorption peak on the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst was the strongest at 2123 cm-1, indicating the highest content of Cu+ on the reduced CuCo/(Si-100H) [35]. This may be more conducive to providing non-dissociated adsorbed CO⁎ species and migrating to the Co0 active sites, thereby promoting the growth of C-C chains. The surface structure of calcined CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts are depicted in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that all catalysts emerged typical type-IV isotherms with a H2 type hysteresis loop, which are the characteristics of mesoporous materials with nanoscale dimensions [36]. The pore size distribution curve shows that the pore size of all catalysts is concentrated between 3.1–5.8 nm, indicating a narrow nanopore distribution. The texture properties obtained using the BJH model on the isotherm desorption and adsorption branches of the corresponding catalyst are listed in Table 2 , including SBET, Vp and Dp. The specific surface area of calcined CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts remains all around 400 m2/g, the pore volume based on desorption and adsorption isotherms is maintained at 0.49 cm3/g and 0.53 cm3/g, respectively. The values of the pore size were observed in the range of 4.16–4.26 nm. This indicates that Si-OH has no remarkable effect on the texture properties of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts, as the amount of metal Cu and Co loaded on each catalyst remains consistent. Accordingly, the specific surface area and pore structure of a series of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts should not interfere with the structure-activity relationship discussed below. The XRD of the calcined, reduced and used CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 4 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 31.3°, 36.8°, 59.3° and 65.2° can be attributed to Co3O4 phases (JCPDS 43–1003), and the characteristic diffraction peaks at 35.5°, 38.7° can be assigned to CuO phases (JCPDS 45–0937), indicating that Co3O4 and CuO phases coexisted in the calcined CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts [33,37]. As shown in Fig. 4(b)(c), all the CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts exhibited the diffraction peaks at 2θ of 43.3°, 50.4° assigned to Cu phases (JCPDS 04–0836) [38]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Co species were not detected in the XRD. Thus, it is implied that the CuO becomes the Cu0 phase after reduction or reaction, while the Co species remained highly dispersed on the SiO2 support and below the detection threshold of XRD. According to XRD results, different H2O2 pretreatment temperatures have no significant effect on the size of metal particles in CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts after calcination, reduction, or reaction. Therefore, more intuitive TEM characterization is needed to further confirm the morphology and dispersion degree of the catalyst. The TEM and HRTEM images were performed to confirm the hyperfine structure of the reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 . From the TEM images (5a1-d1), it can be observed that compared with the control CuCo/(Si) catalyst, the metal particles significantly decrease with the elevation of H2O2 pretreatment temperature. The CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with the highest activity possesses the smallest metal nanoparticles. It is noteworthy that when the temperature continues to rise to 120 °C, the metal particles show obvious agglomeration again, which may be attributed to intimate contact between the excessive negative charged Si-OH and positively charged metals in the CuCo/(Si-120H) catalyst [39,40]. From the HRTEM images (Fig. 5 a2-d2), the lattice spacing of 0.213 nm, 0.202 nm, 0.241 nm, and 0.209 nm were clearly exposed in the reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalyst, assigned to CoO (200), Co (111), Cu2O (111), and Cu (111) species, respectively. Combined with the XRD results after reduction (Fig. 4b), it is proved that in addition to Cu0 species, there are also Cu2O, CoO, and Co0 species in the reduced catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the distribution of HAADF-STEM and EDX elements for the reduced CuCo/(Si-100H) catalysts. Obviously, the Cu, Co, Si, and O elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the reduced CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with the best ethanol synthesis performance. H2-TPR spectra was used to further investigate the phases in the calcined catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 , all the CuCo/(Si-TH) catalyst exhibits a broad peak at 200–330 °C, which is closely connected to the content of Si-OH. It is generally believed that the small peak centered at 217 °C (lower temperature) was attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO→Cu0/+, the prominent peak appeared at 236 °C (moderate temperature) attributed to the reduction of Co3+→Co2+, and the reduction peak at 258 °C (higher temperature) attributed to the reduction of large particle CuO and a small amount of Co2+→Co0 [41–43]. Compared with the CuCo/(Si) catalyst, the reduction peak of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalyst pretreated with H2O2 shifts significantly towards lower temperatures, attributed to better dispersion of metal particles. However, TEM results showed partial particle aggregation on the surface of CuCo/(Si-120H) catalyst, which may be due to the high hydroxyl density leading to the aggregation of partially anchored active species. Overall, the H2O2 pretreatment of the SiO2 support still promoted the dispersion of metal particles. On the other hand, after pretreatment of the support with H2O2, the peak area of hydrogen consumption was significantly reduced, indicating that Si-OH can effectively inhibit the excessive reduction of Cu and Co, making the reduction process more difficult. This is closely related to the generation of more Cu+ species in the in situ CO-DRIFTS results. XPS analysis was also conducted to investigate the surface phase composition and electronic structure of the reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts. As exhibited in Fig. 8(a) , the characteristic peak at 933.3 eV in the Cu 2p region is assigned to the 2p3/2 peaks of the reduced metal Cu0/+ as reported in literature [44,45]. No characteristic peak or satellite peak (940 − 945 eV) related to Cu2+ is observed, implying that Cu2+ is completely reduced to Cu+ or/and Cu0 after an activation process [25]. To gain further insights, the Cu LMM XAES spectra were obtained to discriminate the copper species with low valence. As shown in Fig. 8(b), there are broad asymmetric peaks at binding energies of approximately 573.9 eV and 570.6 eV. Although it cannot be accurately fitted into two overlapping peaks, it can still clearly confirm the stable coexistence of Cu+and Cu0 species on the surface of the reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalyst [46,47]. In addition, the Co 2p spectra in Fig. 8(c) shows two main characteristic peaks at approximately 798.5 eV and 780.5 eV, which can be ascribed to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2, respectively, and the corresponding satellite peaks are located at 803.6 eV and 787.9 eV. For Co 2p3/2, the binding energy at 780.5 eV is ascribed as CoO species [48]. Although it is hard to observe a significant Co0 binding energy peak below 780 eV, combined with previous TEM characterization, it can be concluded that Co2+ species are mainly present in the reduced catalyst, with a small amount of Co0 . The content of Cu and Co on the catalyst surface was obtained by XPS surface analysis, as shown in Table 3 . It can be seen that the Cu/Co molar ratio on the surface of reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts presents an inverted volcanic trend with the increase of H2O2 pretreatment temperature. On the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst surface with the best ethanol synthesis performance, the Cu/Co molar ratio reaches the lowest value of 0.92. According to the results of XRD and TEM, an appropriate amount of Si-OH may preferentially promote the dispersion of Co species, while excessive Si-OH (pretreated with H2O2 at 120 °C) will preferentially lead to the aggregation of Co particles. On the basis of above analysis, the change in the Cu/Co ratio indicates a strong interaction effect between Si-OH and metal species occurred on the surface of CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts. Time-resolved infrared absorption spectra were acquired for the reference CuCo/(Si) catalysts and optimized CuCo/(Si-100H). As displayed in Fig. 9 , a distinct vibrational band centered at 3014 cm-1 in CuCo/(Si) and CuCo/(Si-100H) catalysts arises from adsorbed CH₄ species [49]. The spectral region between 2961 and 2857 cm-1 exhibits three prominent peaks at 2961, 2928, and 2857 cm-1, assigned to the ν(CH) stretching modes of surface-bound CH₃CH₂O⁎ species [50]. Concurrently, a δ(CH) deformation vibration of the same CH₃CH₂O⁎ species manifests as a sharp absorption at 1303 cm-1 [51]. Further analysis reveals two diagnostic bands at 1560 and 1358 cm-1 −1, assigned to νas(OCO) asymmetric stretching and δ(CH) bending vibrations of adsorbed HCOO⁎ intermediates, respectively [52]. Additional spectral signatures at 1458 cm-1 −1 and 1395 cm-1 −1 were conclusively linked to δ(CH₃) and δ(CH) deformation modes of CH₃CHO⁎ surface species [49]. These vibrational fingerprints collectively elucidate the cascade of C-H bond activation and oxygenate formation pathways under operando conditions. For the CuCo/(Si) catalyst (Fig. 9a), as the reaction unfolds over time, operando DRIFT spectra indicate that the intensity of the diffraction peak of CH4 exceeds that of the CH₃CH₂O⁎ intermediates. Conversely, on the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst pretreated with H2O2, the characteristic peak intensity of the CH₃CH₂O⁎ intermediate is greater than that of methane. This finding implies that to some extent, the hydroxyl groups generated by H₂O₂ pretreatment of SiO2 hinder the rapid hydrogenation of CHₓ⁎ intermediates, especially the formation of methane. As a result, a substantial amount of CHₓ intermediates on the Cu⁺ active sites bind with non-dissociated CO⁎ to produce CHₓCO⁎ intermediates, which undergo successive hydrogenation steps to form CH₃CH₂O⁎ intermediates, ultimately leading to the generation of ethanol. It is noteworthy that, compared to the CuCo/Si catalyst, the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst exhibits a more prominent δ(CH) vibrational characteristic peaks of CH₃CH₂O⁎ species. In addition, for the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst pretreated with H2O2, the intensity of the characteristic adsorption peak of formate remains relatively unchanged, indicating that the Si-OH on the surface of the catalyst do not exert a significant impact on the synthesis and decomposition of the formate intermediates. In essence, the Si-OH on the CuCo/(Si-100) catalyst curtail the rapid hydrogenation of CHₓ⁎ intermediates, thereby enhancing the likelihood of CHₓ⁎ intermediates coupling with non-dissociated CO⁎ to generate CHₓCO⁎, and consequently promoting ethanol production. 3.3 Mechanism study on the promotion of Si-OH in ethanol synthesis Firstly, the Si-OH content on the surface of the support treated with H2O2 at different temperatures was verified through infrared skeleton analysis, indicating that the higher the H2O2 treatment temperature, the higher the Si-OH content on the surface of the SiO2. According to the performance evaluation results of different CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts, the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst pretreated with H2O2 at 100 °C exhibit the best ethanol catalytic performance, which can simultaneously achieve the highest CO conversion, ethanol selectivity, and STY of total alcohol and ethanol. The EDX element distribution map proves that Cu, Co, O, and Si elements in CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst can be uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface. Combining TEM images and XPS characterization, to a certain extent, Si-OH prone to promotes the dispersion of Co species, attributed to the formation of Si-O-Co covalent bonds between Si-OH and the Co, which facilitates the uniform anchoring of metal ions on the surface of SiO2 support. However, excessive Si-OH will lead to the aggregation of Co species. Furthermore, the presence of Co0, Co2+, Cu0, and Cu+ species on the reduced CuCo/(Si-TH) catalysts was confirmed by combining the XRD and HRTEM characterization. in situ CO-DRIFTS also clearly indicated that the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with the best ethanol catalytic performance had the most Cu+ species and more Co0 species, which was conducive to the adsorption of non dissociated CO⁎ and the formation of C1 intermediate (CHx ⁎), respectively. It is assumed that the numerous Cu+-Co0 synergistic sites facilitate CO⁎ insertion into the CHx ⁎ intermediates thus leading to a higher selectivity to ethanol. What's more, operando DRIFT characterization further proving that the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst effectively inhibited the excessive hydrogenation of CHx ⁎ intermediates, which is beneficial for the coupling of CHx ⁎-CO⁎. Simultaneously, CO⁎ reacted with Si-OH to generate HCOO⁎ intermediates, followed by hydrogenated to form CHxO⁎ species. The produced CHxO⁎ species were inserted into CHx ⁎ or alkyl chain CxHy ⁎ species to obtain CxHyCHO⁎ species and further hydrogenated to C2+OH [41,53]. According to the above characterization results and catalytic performance, a cooperative reaction mechanism over the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst is proposed in Fig. 10 . In short, the highly dispersed Cu and Co species and abundant Cu+-Co0 synergistic active sites with close vicinity are responsible for the high ethanol yield of CuCo/(Si-100H) catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, we report here that the specific role of hydroxyl groups on the simple CuCo catalyst without additives, which portrayed a critical role in the direct synthesis of ethanol from syngas. The content of Si-OH significantly increases with the increase of temperature for H2O2 pretreatment of SiO2. To a certain extent, Si-OH significantly promotes the dispersion of metal particles and also changes the degree of reduction of active metals. However, excessive Si-OH causes metal particles to aggregate, greatly reducing the efficiency of ethanol synthesis. The CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with a proper surface Si-OH exhibited the best catalytic performance. The CO conversion is as high as 37.8 % under a high space velocity of 3000 h-1 with a ethanol selectivity of 29.0 %, a STY toward total alcohol of 58.6 mg/mLcat·h. Combined with various characterizations and contrast experiments, it is indicated that an appropriate amount of Si-OH is beneficial for the formation of the most Cu+ species, leading to the formation of a large amount of non dissociated CO⁎, which could react with the dissociative adsorbed Co0-CHx ⁎ to produce ethanol. Their synergy is the key to stimulate ethanol selectivity. These understandings on the catalytic behaviors of Si-OH in the CuCo catalyst create a new perspective for the practical applications of catalysts in thermal catalytic synthesis of ethanol. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the role of hydroxyl groups on SiO2 in regulating the electronic and structural properties of copper and cobalt species is of great significance for direct conversion of syngas to ethanol. Here we report that the hydroxyl groups are efficiently modulated by pretreatment of SiO2 with H2O2 at different temperatures and obtain the CuCo/(Si-100H) catalyst with appropriate amounts of Si-OH. It can simultaneously possesses the highest CO conversion (37.8 %) and ethanol selectivity (29.0 wt %), together with excellent ethanol space-time yield of 17.0 mg/mLcat·h. The excellent performance can be attributed to the fact that the Si-OH promotes the dispersion and reduction degree of Cu and Co by a strong metal-support interaction, resulting in the formation of more Cu+-Co0 synergistic active sites, known as the key sites for C2-oxygenate formation. Among them, Co0 species facilitate the dissociation of CO and generat a large amount of CHx ⁎ intermediates, which could react with the CO⁎ species adsorbed on the adjacent Cu+ species, greatly stimulating the formation of ethanol. More significantly, Operando DRIFT characterization revealed that the moderate incorporation of hydroxyl groups effectively suppresses CHₓ⁎ hydrogenation into methane. Consequently, a substantial amount of CHx ⁎ intermediates engaged in the propagation of the carbon chain, thus facilitating the production of ethanol. This investigation offers a facile preparation method and insights to improve the ethanol yield for direct syngas conversion.

coredata.dc:title: The role of hydroxyl groups on SiO2 supported CuCo catalyst in the direct synthesis of ethanol from syngas
